poems.title: a pearl is born from a desecrated oyster
poems.body:
i dredge my hands through hallowed ground
bring them up dirty, nails cracked,
grasping bloody, foraged fragments,

shadows hidden in the sacred 
that we hoped could never be,

for what is faith without doubt,
without violence and pearls?

and here is a word: desecrated — 
purity violated, corrupted.

i dig for desecrated things.
many i have cracked, as have my parents,
as have the gears and levers.

i wash them, affix to them scrap,
gold, and coffee grounds. piece potshards
together. mend their wounds
with lacquer. sheen of *kintsugi*,
shining veins of once-broken things.

even this ground was once desecrate.
it may be again. i too am desecrate.
this changes nothing.
i will continue to mend.

poems.title: after wires
poems.body:
there is faith and decay in the mist:
a canticle. we return and return.
there is rust upon these vines
that line the halls of mist.
the patterns on my skin have grown thick
with dew, with residue. you'd think they'd
wash each other, but it is not so. they breed.

this body was a cask for something foul.
we chiseled holes to keep it cleansed.
now our days are drilling holes, filling holes,
drilling once again. the way scars heal 
when you let gauze fuse over raw flesh
and tear it off each day.
knotted. fungal. aching,
a mess of wires.

the truth about man* and machine.
*tetsuo* reforged. The Fetishist of Rust and Cables.
coaxial life-forms. self
outside medicalization.
binary as information.
a body forged of copper-oxidizing:
ink as wires as transfer of sound
as communion of revelry.
kneeling at the idol of coil.

poems.title: Meditation I
poems.body:
Cockpit lights flicked softly,
Forest glow upon your face.
You told me, “We are peaceful.”
I told you, “This is grace.”
The ceiling was on fire,
Dust choked the human race,
Yet still we kept on climbing,
Slipping up towards outer space.

poems.body:
Jay used to take me driving late at night —
forgotten roads, dark runways.
“Someday I’ll be among the stars.”
When he left town he told me he was 
apprenticing under the first man on the moon.
In three months he returned,
tattered NASA cap crumpled on the floor.
I asked what was it like to be an astronaut.
*IgaveuptoomuchmathI’mfineonEarth.*
Now he sits in his basement breathing grass,
grieving Ziggy Stardust,
another stoned-dead simopath
waiting for the flies.

In three months he returned, tattered NASA cap crumpled on the floor. I asked what was it like to be an astronaut. *IgaveuptoomuchmathI’mfineonEarth.* Now he sits in his basement breathing grass, grieving Ziggy Stardust, another stoned-dead simopath waiting for the flies.

poems.title: PMMA
poems.body:
The ice age begins with a whisper —
soft, the brushing of hands unwanted.
No tethers bind us but we,
the mutualist fantasy:
everything will be okay,
as it was at T’s that night,
the mural and metocin words were
“love you I love you”
as if we knew each other then.

—“I need to treat drugs like they’re drugs,” 
not like they’re you. Dripping unsaid.
I fantasize about DOC in darkness,
a world in which I am a no one
and you are a pillar of light,
sparking the stars to the sky

poems.title: She, Starlight Spirit
poems.body:
There were fireworks over the field, mist-night,
I asked what’s it like to grow up.
Pause. Waiting for a smile, something — 
you told me about polyphasic sleeping,
how the Ubermensch only takes naps,
how you’ve dreamt of moving to Windtown,
garage life, meet no one, exist in between.
You’d walk only night streets, blackened yet hallow,
moving through sleepers to tend to their dreams.
"It’s why no one’s happy, cuz nobody does it,
cuz if someone did they’d forget who they are."

poems.title: — noun — a scream
poems.body:
A shift. My breath as smoke,
poisoning the air between.

Your hand twirling hair, your mouth
grasping, some noise to fill the void.

Silence is a church no longer.
You hate your egg sandwich. You want tea.

Do you remember when summer was ourselves and each other?
Now in carelessness or malice we lost both.

The café door slams.
Footsteps on concrete. The empty scream.

The empty scream.

poems.body:
We used to go down by the power plant and smoke.
You’d pass me the joint and say,
“I hope someday we’ll be here again.”
You always looked up at the moon.
One day I asked why — this town is a shithole —
“But I am the ocean and you are the waves.”
On Monday the eighth you didn’t say anything
and on Tuesday the ninth you drove your car
down the sand to the bottom of the sea.
I wish I had held your hand that day
when we sat by the broken converter
and stared at the frayed wire
crying electric-blue.

I wish I had held your hand that day when we sat by the broken converter and stared at the frayed wire crying electric-blue.

poems.title: Meditation II
poems.body:
We walked into the valley,
And your hair — it shone like lace.
I turned around and you had gone,
Of your steps there was no trace.
Dust swept o’er the barren ground
While death’s cold wind gave chase;
In nighttime fear I reached for you,
But what I found was my own face.

poems.body:
let there be light - heat -
the prophet comes three times - we call for him a fourth -
we are insatiable -

poems.title: Profound Mysticism, Always Expanding
poems.body:
I am freed through chain
links to the earth.
The ancient tradition:
*Let go your thoughts! Unimportant*
*you! Surrender! (enlightenment)*

I thought my way out of Paris
when my parents,
France, gave me an ultimatum.
*You leave school, the disappointment.*
it’s not that I hate academia -
Comp Lit Comp Arts Contemporary Independent Southeast Asian Cinema Analysis I just 
don’t wake up.

*Wake up!*
My first lucid dream
was in a beach house. Low lit
and lone, I became aware
of a darkened place. 
Soon enough it swallowed me.

I don’t hate sleeping,
just sleepwalking. I want sleep
to begin and end under the covers.
None of this drive a tenton automobile
awake-as-an-amobea crap.
When I say that my phone is dead
*I want it to be gone.*

poems.title: Allow, Allow, Allow
poems.body:
& when I do urn lines of Erlenmeyer
claw at the gates. I am a man
who feeds on sin-begotten blood,
bones to plaster in obfuscate sight.
A pause paints the poem with poison.
Nothing is truly revealed in an instant;
the TAZ comes and goes, drums beat
in the ironworks. Nothing
is truly revealed in an instant.

I practice locked in structure. Spontaneous
to find myself a madman. Google tells me
that madmen aren’t mad men or sad men but
glad men - sixteen Valium and a docco’s Seroquel
(in truth)
spell enlightenment.               さ          と          り
madness is my veins and when I let it bleed I
feel. No injections, not anymore.
I thought the wound 
		had
	closed.  I am born in a new direction.

Does ocean need a shore?
On Earth one ocean, one shore,
but if neighbors go to war what, then,
is a shore?

poems.title: Manic, Inaccurate References to Martial or Religious Texts
poems.body:
I am grateful for Arianna.
The death-throes of the verb,
cries Sisyphus, who flew too close to
	the sun.

I am grateful for everyone who is not Tom,
Tom the fuck-up eternal.
So sayeth the Dharma:
as we haughty humans live out
dust-pans and dreary dream-lives,
*Greenfields Aging Aid Center*, house of the hobbled,
Tom will live forever.
He is the thirsty ghost which
moves our wine to whiskey,
a red-cheeked dreadnought.
His circle of hell is particular to après-ski.

Zombie Juice, Psalm Trees 4:21:
“Dab or die tryin’, on the road to Zion.”
My ex saw God in Zion.
They saw it in Cambodia, too.
They never saw Zombie Juice.
I only read of what they saw
months later, though I was there.
Past dusk I put my chewed-up wad of cinnamon gum
on a journal page, oozed it around.
Seconds later came a line of jungle ants,
tiny translucent weevils glomming up our headlamp.
I saw fleas, they saw God.
Come to think of it, we also saw
Zombie Juice.
He came later.

I tried to make sense of hymns.
I got as far as “Thigh Kingdom cum.”
Fucking weird,
church.

Every time I mention someone’s name
in a poem,
I mean it.
That’s why I mention Zombie Juice.
What you mistook for a necrotic fruit drink
is in fact a Brooklyn-based braineater
rapping groove on Flatbush Ave.
He is not broke, he does not make jokes.
So it is said.

Lesson 1: Respect Your Elders.
I’m not much of an artist
myself, you understand,
just an esoteric channeler
lynching divinity-specks on paper.
I share this dead divine
with friends at workshops,
Gabby’s room, you understand,
they grok and groove — 
ooh, ahh, can’t trust it.
*Never trust a prankster,
how’s that for the motto
of my greatest heroes,
just one small spotlight on Kesey
They’re saying, ‘Look at him— 
the promising novelist … 
once surrounded by thousands …
and now only these few’ … 
But I can—*
we build ash-myths of ourselves
to watch in hypnagogue.
My hair will grow long when I leave.
Empath, expath,
buried deep in shadow.
Sepsis.
My hair will grow long when I leave.

poems.title: Untitled (Since Every Work Needs One)
poems.body:
The stretching of a word becomes like air,
soft as sand. Patterns repeat themselves
in life as in death. Cycles of rust.

In this age I am not welcome. There is something there,
never here. Often overwhelmed,
I’m neither here nor here. Undone,

I see myself in shapes: vanguard, harlequin, Sometimes-All.
Things are forgotten — the dishes lie unused.
The same voice says the same things.

As if enlightened!
Spit on my enlightenment.
Shit on it.

I find awareness in facts,
in sight. It comes and goes. My eyes blur
and my prescription changes. Left alone in the dark

I               I       I    I  I
always I. I tell a story
on I, my filler word,

and so I decay. I’ve forgotten how to ask for help.
Even if I could, I do not know what I need.
I suspect Milo knows.

What dark energies do I project?
Wishing it was gone, the world returns to fragments.
Catherine is ever unsympathetic.

I! Equal parts god and ghost,
in hellish words repeated. 
When hellish worlds receded where was I?

Gone again to air. I think I know myself.
The faucet leaks and leaks.
I wish these poems would do the same

poems.title: Road
poems.body:
Word is the debts are all incurred.
Our conductor asks for forty-two cents, his hands
outstretched. Brother, are you gone?
The images do not align. They are my prayers.
Forest stillness ceaseless beckons,
a winding way to Eden.

A green sheet-sign propped on posts of steel: Fourteen Miles. Eden.
We have so far to go. With these poems I have incurred
nothing. Through these tryptaminic beckons
we are moved to build a world without my hands.
I thought those pills were prayers.
Brother, where have you gone?

Gawain, where have you gone?
Gone ahead to Eden?
Each morning I’m ablaze with prayers
and still to all but me am I incurred.
The silence has no hands.
Still it beckons.

The bell-gong-chime alert list beckons
to the trees. When all the red leaves are gone
we see the freeway that I’ve built without my hands.
Fourteen miles — Eden.
So it is said. So it is said in beckons.
Must I wade above my neck to gather prayers?

A year ago today I thought that tabs were prayers.
A year ago today I yelled aloud my beckons,
you came close, learned a roll, compassion I’d incurred.
Your screams made me find gone
and you screamed more. Who am I talking to? No one can build Eden
without hands.

See I know nothing like the back of my hands,
of which I know nothing. These words shapeless prayers
and now where is Eden?
No lights along the road nor signs nor beckons
and all the passengers are emptied, gone,
replaced by debts I have incurred.

Visions of my hands become like beacons,
prayers in the road that has not gone.
Perhaps Eden, too, we have incurred.

poems.title: From Form
poems.body:
Living indifferent.
Another harmless genocide:
something small, something large, something spurious
in vaguish nouns like neosthesia
keep us rapt,
our essence liminal,

croaking sub-liminal,
the castle in December, indifferent
to snow, dinner on the first floor *whore d’ervs* rapt
(banquet sounds) rather genocide,
ain’t it? Take off your mask and look me in the face—*neosthesia*— 
about time, Face the Spurious.

Words are always in focus. Spurious,
they knock and knock. When living is liminal
can we choose between Zoloft and neosthesia?
Pause. I thought so. You remain faithfully indifferent.
True to type, again-again genocide,
wrapped the whole mess is rapped watching rapt

a conflagration end of days SFX spurious rapt
& so entrapped. Spurious
I begin a sentence how it ended. Genocide?
The clock ticks knock-knock, sound and no form. Liminal.
You and I are so different. You and I both indifferent.
I wish a song to sing that ripples thru my legs, neosthesia—

a noun like a verb means new feeling neosthesia,
kick down the doors the word’s keep is rapt
enrapture indifferent
colorful biscuit kick down the doors you spurious
limp kid. Whose voice can cast the spells with liminal
metrics measures back again to genocide?

We can’t stand the genocide.
Our geas: inject neosthesia
in wounded Man. Thus ends genocide. Methods liminal,
figure one: the seasons. Viewers rapt.
Searching and searching through spurious,
we find our own lives in different

phases, barbecue, two-tryst, genocide, always rapt
to nesothesia, shiny and shimmering, spurious
feelings, liminal. I must be indifferent.

poems.title: What is Made of Iron? (Here is a Question That No One Will Answer)
poems.body:
I am lost.
In hopes of the mountain, sweeping statements
fail continuous. The past in vibrations:
my mind decried,
stanza after stanza
I write senseless salvation.

Made word six salvation.
Something I have lost
or never found. Repeating the stanza:
We used to go down by the power plant. Smoke. Statements
to read light. Self by self decried — 
portentous vibrations,

phone’s endless vibrations.
*SAMSUNG: AS DEAD AS US*. From clay, salvation.
From whence the mire of Prometheus decried,
so too our blood and bone. Alive, as a phone. Forges of the lost
process syrups, our state mints.
One title, one line, one stanza — 

by-the-book assembly. Start with stanza.
Broken, as bread. Start with stanza. Vibrant vibrations,
vital libations, sibilant statements:
meaningless, as meadow. Ill salvation,
ill litation. I am lost.
Siddhartha, once decried

in everything! Over-formal, low marks. In everything decried.
Back where we began: the stanza.
Sometimes made of lines, lines often lost.
Anathemic, as class rhetoric. Grok and groove, the vibrations :::::
fuck this poem with no salvation.
Statements statements, statements, statements

statements!
Full stop. Dee cried.
Formless, as salvation.
The words are wrong, but the stanza
looks fine. だいじょうぶ。I cracked my phone between vibrations,
machinations, acting lost.

Vibrant vibrations, vital libations, sibilant statements: meaningless, as meadow. Ill salvation, ill litation. I am lost. Siddhartha, once decried in everything! Over-formal, low marks. In everything decried. Back where we began: the stanza. Sometimes made of lines, lines often lost. Anathemic, as class rhetoric. Grok and groove, the vibrations ::::: fuck this poem with no salvation. Statements statements, statements, statements statements! Full stop. Dee cried. Formless, as salvation. The words are wrong, but the stanza looks fine. だいじょうぶ。I cracked my phone between vibrations, machinations, acting lost.

poems.title: To Griffin, We Are Made as Unmade
poems.body:
These are the makings of a god.
Crack my hollow bones
to rush forth brine.
These are the makings of a broad
spectrum. We’ve found analysis
many different ways;

to walk alone down drifting ways
wondering will there ever be god
and will the *Times* publish an analysis
of the matter in her bones?
She will have shoulders like yours: broad,
hair smelling of brine,

tips dipped in sea *to remember*. The scent of brine
can be found many different ways:
pickling, road safety, broad,
vague feelings of love. I have seen the eye of god
buried in these bones.
Finding it through analysis?

Like finding zero through analysis.
Unnamed, impossible. The scent of brine
that shaped these bones
in pencil, many ancient ways
equated to god
by those who don’t understand the vast and broad

makings of a broad-
shouldered analysis-
smiting god
living in the scent of brine
as she does the highwire walkway
and our lowered bones,

our femur bones,
the makings of our Earth are broad
yet whichever way
I run the analysis — 
the rocks, the scent of brine,
god.

Scientists ran ancient bones through analysis — 
*the broad wild’scape of human feeling emerged from brine —*
priests say we are shaped in the ways of a god —

poems.title: Imagined Years
poems.body:
Call me by my name
and I will call you yours.
Ask me what is paradise.
I will tell true.
I’m writing a song
from your letters.

Leaves fall, my child practices letters
on a chalkboard. His name
is Samson, from a song
on the radio. *Powerful Samson*. He’s yours— 
if not by blood, by virtue. When measured true,
between me and a chalkboard sands paradise.

What *is* paradise?
You wrote it in letters
from New Zealand. At eighteen I didn’t know the true
from false of it, but I heard it in your name.
*Yah-nah, spelled Jana*. Yours
with mine, like a song.

I thought no wrong had ever come from a song,
especially not *Cheeseburger in Paradise*.
I thought I’d wrote the first wrong song with yours — 
too stuck in my own mad melody, the letters
and poems grew thin. Call me by my name
and hope I am true.

From true, untrue.
A swaying song— 
frost heaves, blues in two names.
Roll up paradise
in a few letters,
my name, yours.

Something should be yours
by virtue or by blood. That much is true.
I’ll send you a photo of the letters.
Even after all these years you’ll send me a song.
I do not know if there are names
for those vast remains of paradise.

Yours is a tall-tree song
of true palm psalms. In paradise
all letters are a name.

poems.title: deterioration
poems.body:
a word becomes itself
among others.
education: your mind pushed, pulled.
do not renounce
that knowledge grooove
that lives X

the cross hangs X
will you hang yourself?
do you dance to the groove
anymore? the lives of ((you/others))
on the line would you renounce
—howmuchhaveipulled—

my ankle pulled
i could not walk X
days/nights in itself
a word to renounce.
supposedly others
hear the groove

i do not ~groove~
i’m upwards pulled
out the water leave the others
down stay stay X
WE RENOUNCE
THIS LIFE ITSELF

A SIN IT BITES ITSELF.
deep dark grove
draw the path. renounce.
mind/body/muscles/other fetish things pulled
X
X X X/the others

fuck the others
we, itself,
me x
the groove
pulled
me to renounce

to renounce to renounce the others
i pulled itself
out of. the groove. into darkness.

poems.title: The Ordinary Sestina
poems.body:
It’s a long time since we were by the brook.
You and your values
have changed since then. No longer— 
I’m not particularly inclined to write this sestina
but I’m forcing myself to practice
in this blood red journal.

*Rap is always about rap, poems about poetry.* Jotted in the journal,
inescapable truth which form can barely brook.
Days and days, a poem about my mother, I practice
and practice. Still the poem values
only itself. Take, for instance, this sestina.
I didn’t want it to be about poetry. Yet! 39 lines, no shorter, no longer.

Of course, a sestina always ends up longer
than I’d think. Space on a page does not correlate to the marks in a journal.
Carissa told me she became a poet through the trials of sestina.
Six words, 39-line. Your tears become a brook.
You call me abusive cuz my safety, my values,
I tell you to get the fuck out of my life, you piece of shit rapist.
Your mask is off, but you have so much practice

catching people off guard that I can never tell. You should practice
drying your tears just a little longer— 
too quick of a recovery. I see it. Theater values
the genuine. As do I. Says so in this journal:
*A decision has been made. Her tears drew a much wider brook
than yours may ever know.* It’s followed by a small sestina,

36-line, forgot the envoi. A complicated form, that sestina,
but always worth the practice.
It thinks carefully about what matters, and will brook
no deviations of form: 39-line, no-shorter-no-longer. 
Just a couple jots in the journal.
Form has its values:

To make you question yours, always seen in a sestina
you cross out in your journal. Perdomo said poetry is practice,
a few minutes a day, a careful walk by the brook.

poems.title: To Isadora
poems.body:
Once, we laid long in your driveway
to spell out the stars. We had pillows,
blankets,
		creases.

I remember this. I wrote it down.

	Left of the bathroom
I opened a door I never noticed. 
Everything was blue inside.
Teal walls.	Ocean photographs.

Your kitchen was really two rooms,
		but it took me a while to see.
	A sink, an oven, hanging pots and pans
like green-white wide open.
	Darkened-floor couches
		in a demanding, ancient cavern.

I remember this. 		It was real.

We found water pouring
	from an unknown hole in a basement gallon,
		stored for end-of-days.
I stayed to plug the hole,
		you 			went looking for a bucket.
	Not long after, we stopped speaking.

I remember this.						It was a pillow fort
filled with candles.			
				They burnt my hair.

I wrote it down.             Left of the bathroom I opened a door I never noticed. Everything was blue inside. Teal walls.            Ocean photographs. Your kitchen was really two rooms,                         but it took me a while to see.             A sink, an oven, hanging pots and pans like green-white wide open.             Darkened-floor couches                         in a demanding, ancient cavern. I remember this.                         It was real. We found water pouring             from an unknown hole in a basement gallon,                         stored for end-of-days. I stayed to plug the hole,                         you                                     went looking for a bucket.             Not long after, we stopped speaking. I remember this.                                                                        It was a pillow fort filled with candles.                                                                                     They burnt my hair.

poems.title: Tattoo
poems.annotatedBody: There is a piece of damage on my old, mad bones.     My muscles cannot contain it.     In the wind found the crane, clamored its neck.     Clasped its cables.     We were born to shovel dirt — I left my hands behind in it.     Places on my body, born with pricks.     I am wicked when I crawl in it.     It is she, a gargoyle wind from the streets around grove.     From flesh she is mine, born in my breasts as wind brings the traveler home, now mad murderous at the ones who created her.     This cannot be it.     I have never been as mad as at my father, who will not give his son to wind.     If I could let fear wind long like cables of the crane, imagined to be yellow, I could be a hairless automatic who wished herself unborn.     A breath of tracheal wind — each day I must ration being born.

poems.title: Gaze
poems.body:
Soft lipstick
in the hour of the subway.
Anxious eyes on
clicking heels
echo the silence.
				I dream in binary
					and in half rip through my skin.

											Defining the moment
										a man scooches closer
									I say my name, my
													pro-
nouns,
			I define gaze as unending
				and liminal as death.
										And we are always liminal.
Let your fears dress how they want,
	scream at them: drag.
		See how they feel.
									Don't be surprised when their stiletto
				rips open your throat 			after sunrise,
when you think the worst has passed.

There is no shade of concealer
						for the years that have not come.

Let your fears dress how they want,             scream at them: drag.                         See how they feel.                                                                                                             Don't be surprised when their stiletto                                                 rips open your throat                                     after sunrise, when you think the worst has passed. There is no shade of concealer                                                                         for the years that have not come.

poems.title: raw
poems.body:
i am a cheating vegetarian.
*“meat is murder.”*
machines
grind screaming cows to carpets
for raw laughter and fourth of july. 
biting blood. blemishes. bile.
people say
*wow i could never eat like you
	haha, saving the planet!*

i can tell them
fifty-one percent of greenhouse gases 
come from animal agriculture.
and also, did you know,
one hundred corporations are responsible
for seventy-one percent of carbon emissions?
who gives a fuck about veganism?
these are end times, sister,
and i am useless.
ditching meat
won’t stop our puppet government
from broiling the earth
to blaze.

i can’t tell them
i used to leave the grill after a bad rush
and go to the bathroom,
squeeze my flab. choke
my cock-meat dead
until i knew i wouldn’t cry.
lock myself in the supply shed
and gorge on bacon and muffin mix
for tomorrow’s customers.
squeeze in my chest.
flatten the goo
to get rid of my finger tracks.
it always stayed slimy.

milk. cream. raw, raw eggs.
sugar. like clouds
i’d float from my body
to be cold. and raw.

i give my every fiber to unworthiness,
prostrate before loathing. 
these are empty days,
busy with other lives.
i tried to end eating
but i can’t even restrain myself
from licking butter.

poems.title: I AM NOT A GOOD WOODSMAN
poems.body:
I read somewhere
a good woodsman
only has one scar.
I carry scores,
creeping from
hand to heart.
Straw-work 
bandages always fail.

I am never alone.
I don’t let myself.
The tunnel stands ahead again. 
I dreamt the weight was 
too much. I ran back
to the light 
at the entrance.
(Super-frog... almost there!)
When I turned around
the tunnel stood ahead again.

The tunnel stands ahead again. I dreamt the weight was too much. I ran back to the light at the entrance. (Super-frog... almost there!) When I turned around the tunnel stood ahead again.
